Message.Title: Google, Nvidia, Tegra 4 + Chrome OS
Message.Msg: disclaimer: this is all based on blog rumors and my own conjecture. I have started seeing speculation pop up on various blogs that Tegra 4 is competing for design wins in upcoming Chrome OS devices. There is some evidence in the Chromium codebase that at least one Tegra 4-powered Chrome OS device is already being tested by some developers. The codename is "puppy". Yesterday rumors broke out that Google has been designing their own Chromebook--for the first time since the CR-48. It'll supposedly feature amazing resolution (2560x1700) and will include a touch screen in a laptop/notebook form factor. It may also dual-boot Android (again, based on the Chromium codebase and the inclusion of Android libraries therein). Based on the leaked specs/functionality, Tegra 4 should be more than capable of powering such a device device. That said, the leak from yesterday says the device will be called "Pixel" -- which could be a another name for the same device, or a different device altogether (assuming for now that both devices actually exist). Strategically, I think it's very valuable to Google to have Nvidia remain a competitive supplier in the SOC space, especially since TXN has pulled out and won't be investing in supporting Google's platforms. Mediatek has an office in San Jose, but the office is apparently hard to collaborate with, since all key decisions are still run through their HQ in Taiwan, and key product discussions are still held in Mandarin. Huawei is located in Shenzen and also seems to be a difficult/unlikely partner for Google's engineers to collaborate with on a deep level. Nvidia, on the other hand, has their HQ just about 20 minutes from Google's, has hundreds of engineers working on Tegra, and has invested literally billions of dollars in R&D to support the Android market over the last few years. I think Google wants to keep them around. Putting the rumors and my own conjecture together, I think we may learn in the coming months that Google and Nvidia are currently working together on bringing the first real Google-branded Chromebook to the mainstream market. This would also jive well with the rumor that Google may have given the next Nexus 7 design win to Qualcomm... they can't give Nvidia too much love, otherwise QCOM could get hurt feelings :-) To be clear, I'm not suggesting anyone buy Nvidia on the basis that the Tegra 4 *might* be powering a Google-branded Chromebook. I am arguing, however, that it would make sense for Google strategically to nurture Nvidia's efforts in the SOC space, and that there seems to be at least some evidence (in the Chromium codebase) and a growing stream of rumors that the companies are collaborating on a Chrome OS device that sounds really enticing to me as a tech-loving early adopter. I welcome arguments as to why I'm wrong about Google wanting/needing to limit Qualcomm's supplier power, and/or why Tegra 4 wouldn't be a likely candidate for one or more upcoming flagship Chrome devices.

Topic.Title: Apple has $42.40 Cash Per Share (mrq), Nvidiia has $5.50 Cash Per Share (mrq)!

Message.Msg: The relevant factor is cash per share in relation to stock price per share, dummy. In that regard, Nvidia has a MUCH higher percentage of cash to stock price than Apple.

Topic.Title: Apple has $42.40 Cash Per Share (mrq), Nvidiia has $5.50 Cash Per Share (mrq)!

Message.Msg: It's cash per share relative to share price... $5.50/$12.29 is 44.75% of the share price for Nvidia, while $145.88/$468.22 is 31.16% of the share price for Apple. Both have immense cash relative to their market values, but Nvidia has more (again, in relative terms).

Message.Title: 200 Million Workers Want Windows 8 Tablets Not iPads
Message.Msg: (source windows-arm dotcom) Good news for Microsoft: 200 million information workers want Windows tablets, a report from Forrester claimed Monday, quite a few more than the 900,000 Surface RT tablets that IDC estimated have already been sold into the channel. ... The strongest argument for the legitimacy of the data is the sample size of 9,766 information workers that Forrester polled. Typically, market research firms - whether asking questions about technology, political candidates or laundry soap - poll a representative group of respondents and try to extrapolate that data out to the entire population in question, usually Americans or even worldwide users. The larger the sample size, typically, the greater the reliability of the findings.

Message.Title: Steam survey of gamers
Message.Msg: Valve, the company behind Steam, the popular gaming client and digital distribution service for PCs, has revealed the results of its January 2013 global hardware survey. According to the survey, the most popular operating system in use among PC gamers (using Steam) still remains Windows 7 (64-bit) and a vast majority of PC users rely on Intel processors and Nvidia's GeForce graphics cards. While Valve hasn't revealed the total number of respondents to its survey, looking at the more than 56 million people that make up Steam's active user-base, it would be fair to say that the survey results are fairly accurate in representing the hardware configuration of the average PC gamer.

Topic.Title: Steam survey of gamers

Message.Title: "Puppy" Chromebook May Have Nvidia's Tegra 4
Message.Msg: Google has a puppy running around in the Chromium code. ZoomIn addition to reports about Google's in-house Chromebook Pixel, another interesting hint about a new Chrome OS device actually appeared in the Chromium code base on Thursday. It's code-named "puppy" and may sport Nvidia's just-announced Tegra 4 SoC. Is "puppy" and "pixel" the same device? It's possible but unknown at this point. Chrome Story originally found the "puppy" reference housed in Google's Chromium code base, reading: puppy: Add bct ebuild; This includes cfg files for generating a bct that works with T114 dalmore. Searching for the T114 Dalmore reference led the site to an article published by Phoronix. It said that Nvidia released Linux kernel patches back on December 20, 2012, supporting the Tegra 4 SoC under Linux. According to the report, the patches referred to the Tegra 4 as "Tegra 114", and the development/evaluation boards are called "Dalmore" and "Pluto" for the Cortex-A15 MP platform. Thus the Tegra support in Linux allows for a single kernel image to handle Dalmore T114, Pluto T114, and Cardhu T30 (Tegra 3 reference board). Nvidia's Tegra 4 features four ARM Cortex-A15 processor cores and 72 GeForce graphics cores. It also includes a 4G LTE modem and a new camera functionality. That said, Nvidia's Tegra 4 may be what's powering the rumored ChromeBook Pixel laptop which sports a full touchscreen display with a 2560 x 1700 resolution. It definitely makes sense. Chrome Story also points out an interesting line in the Chromium code that seemingly backs another rumor that Chrome OS and Android may soon be merging. The line in question reads: CROS_WORKON_SUBDIR="android-files". Does this mean Chrome OS will have access to Android apps? It's possible that the eventual "merge" will give users the option of installing HTML5-based apps and full-blown, locally-installed apps like 1.5 GB+ games (NOVA 3, Bard's Tale, etc.). At this point, "puppy" could be a laptop, desktop or a set-top box. But right now it's all speculation until Google shows us the real goods this June at Google I/O.

Lets recap 1) QCOM R&D had to BUY / License GPU technology from AMD & PowerVR 2) So much marketing NOISE/FART W8/RT - and they are late by more than 6 months! Quad Cores late by more than 6 months and their initial response - NOBODY NEEDS IT! 2) QCOM is merely touting more dubious GHz as in 5GHz Wifi - #$%$ - my DSL is only going at 3MBPS on a good day and uploading at less than 1MBPS .... and when you are in the bathroom - the $@#$ flows faster. Same thing for the Class 4 LTE 150MBPS ... for practical purposes - there is no perceptible benefit to the end user esp with costly data provisioning to start with. 3. QCOM S800 Recording QHD capaility .... sure we all need that to display on our 720p & 1080p screens - esp the 5" ones! Now on the other hand I would love to get my hands on 1) Shield so my son can play his Android stuff as well as his Steam games away from his desktop and stream it to the big screen to top it. Steam has ~ 56m members! Now if Moga were to do something like that - they would still be at S1 by the time S800 is out. MOGA is merely making a dumb controller - shows how much QCOM understands the ganme market beyond angry birds. 2) HDR - Real Time (almost) High Dynamic Range photography - goes miles beyond Mega pixels - You tout QHD and Mega Pixels when you are brain dead! This makes a difference to every picture you take. Their response - nothing here - sure - where's yours?? Apple has it, NVDA has it - high end cameras all have it - QCOM NO HAVE IT! SHAMEFUL MARKETING FART RESPONSE! 3) The MHz is more than adequate and I am optimistic that the power performance is at least as good or better than what's out there. 4) T4 will be in consumer hands sooner than S800! QCOM marketing is $#!^^!%@ in their pants so they will be FARTING a lot out there - I Love it that NVDA is always leading the way - T2, T3, S/RT, HDR, Shield (NO EQUIVALENT QCOM based product for 2 years at least :) ), Chrome (ahead of QCOM).

Message.Title: new always on HDR will drive Tegra 4 Design wins & consumer adoption big time
Message.Msg: The first smartphone camera that makes easy to take instant and perfect photo's every time will hold a significant advantage with consumer adoption. The biggest hurdle for smartphone users is trying to take a shot in which the background of the subject is bright. But using the 72 GPU cores Tegra 4 as a massively parallel compute engine Nvidia auto-magically merges two exposures taken at the same time in real time so that both the background imagery and the foreground subject are properly exposed which means anyone and everyone will be able to capture gorgeous photos regardless of the background light . If you don't have any idea what I'm referring to, my advice is go find out before you lose a ton of jack After Internet, texting and talking, photography is a killer app

Message.Title: The Power Of Returning Capital To Shareholders
Message.Msg: Just think of the advantages for Nvidia: 1) Blogger articles don't affect the stock price. Marketing just goes about doing their thing. Who cares what some Bozo thinks? 2) What WS analysts say doesn't affect the stock price. Only earnings, stock buybacks, and dividend increases do. 3) Stock Message board activity just dries up. 4) Institutional ownership approaches 100%. Not much available to day trade or short. Everyone is happy and the traders just go away. Case in point look at Microchip Tech today....Once upon a time it was one of the premier day trading blogging semiconductor stocks, but along came the dividend and stock buybacks along with small but reasonable growth with investors being rewarded. I believe Nvidia has embarked on the same path....will see at earnings next week. Just think of the power of an earnings beat, of a guide of 1% to 4% up, stock buyback, and a tiny dividend increase. Then no one will care about Qualcomm's ad campaign are what someonein the "Tech Press" says. JMHO

Message.Title: Why Project Shield will revolutionize gaming as we know it.
Message.Msg: What the heck.. Just thought I'd give the longs a good title.

Message.Title: The growth of the chromebook market
Message.Msg: SOURCE: Forbes Catholic prep school St. Thomas Aquinas in Florida is one of more than 2000 schools to adopt Chromebooks for education according to Jaime Casap, Google‘s Global Education Evangelist. That number represents a healthy 100% growth spurt during the past 3 months. In January 2012 Florida was among the first school districts to move their curriculum to the web, and in turn adopt Chromebooks as a teaching tool. Last week during FETC 2013 — Florida’s annual Technology in Education Conference — educators explained that this shift had a positive impact with three important advantages: “enabling tech support internships, allowing homebound students to collaborate remotely, and teaching students to become digital leaders.” Why are Chromebooks penetrating school systems at this brisk pace? Price is one motivator. With 5 Chromebook models currently available including Acer’s bargain $199 C7, there are viable options for any budget. Google estimates that schools can save an average $4000 per deployed device over three years of ownership. This is partially attributed to lower IT department expenses, as Chrome OS is seamlessly and automatically updated. Web-based management consoles reduce the time it takes admins to deploy changes to users and apps across multiple classrooms. Perhaps the most appealing draw is the security of Chromebooks. When Chromebooks boot up they perform a self-check to ensure no tampering has occurred, and there’s no need for spyware or anti-virus tools. Google’s Chrome OS relies on the company’s existing suite of cloud-based services like Gmail and Google Docs, in addition to many educational apps in the Chrome Web Store. None of these need to be traditionally “installed” and since they don’t run locally, Chromebooks can boot up in under 10 seconds thanks to the lightweight OS. Add in 100GB of cloud storage on Google Drive, and the advantages begin to outweigh those of PCs and even iPads. Chromebooks aren’t just excelling in schools, either. Acer‘s CEO recently revealed that they’ve sold more Chromebooks than Windows 8 devices in the U.S., and now Lenovo is applying their durable ThinkPad branding to a new Chromebook model which gets deployed exclusively to institutions later this month. Are Chromebooks a threat in the consumer market? Not yet, but their budget pricing, growth in the education system, and ease of use will cause a notable uptick in mindshare and word of mouth in years to come. forbesDOTcom/sites/jasonevangelho/2013/02/02/google-in-education-chromebooks-now-embraced-by-more-than-2000-schools/

Topic.Title: The growth of the chromebook market

Message.Msg: Chromebooks advantage: --Low initial cost (SF & HW w/ARM based processor) --Low maintenance cost (automatic updates by Google) --Ease of use --Security --Cloud advantage (storage etc) --Great enterprise appearl --Market development still in nascent stage; few partakers in app processors and OEMs --Likely the fastest growing segment

Topic.Title: Why Project Shield will revolutionize gaming as we know it.

Message.Msg: It's all a game of expectations....but alas it seems like nothing the Tech Press, SA, or Motley Fool, along with comments on this message board seems to move the stock. This is good in my opinion because it leaves all things in the hands of Nvidia's management as they move through middle age and say why fight it....let's give ourselves restricted stock and collect the dividend, do what we like, and return shareholder capital to the investors in the form of stock buybacks and increased dividends....after all we benefit too!!!!!! After all wasn't that what Larry Fink of BlackRock suggested last November when he became a 5% owner.

Topic.Title: Qualcomm shows little interest in making Project SHIELD-like device

Message.Msg: You were to kind to say that QC shows LITTLE INTEREST in developing Project Shield like devices. The blunt truth is that: Qualcomm doesn't yet have what it takes to make a laptop or laptop-like (such as Chromebook) devices. The technical entry barriers for PC/tablets/chromebooks are higher for Qualcomm in comparison with the entry barriers for smartphones. NVIDIA has penetrated the smartphone space - it just needs to catch up to Qualcomm's 25 years lead in this arena. It will get there within a couple of years.

Topic.Title: Qualcomm shows little interest in making Project SHIELD-like device

Message.Msg: They could and perhaps can, but perhaps they see an easier road this year for sure in what they know better than anyone else....How To Play To The Gamer. No offense meant but by their own admission...Nvidia is just a bunch of "Middle Aged Gamers." They are like the Yankees playing in home field in this and I'm sure they love it. Why push hard on Qualcomm in super phones right away...just poke them a little here or there setting up for 2014. If I was a betting man I would bet they are tracking Tegra 4 wins (20,000 units or 5M units each the same) just as they tracked Ivy Bridge notebook wins all being are equal. It worked last year in Ivy Bridge notebooks so why not in phones? It's what you do when you come from a PC background. Mucho small wins are better than a few big wins. Higher gross margin and operating profit when you consider that Nvidia is a NO LAYOFF company and has immense broad based talent in their employees. Put's them all to work. Law of Small Numbers works to their advantage too! In the meantime enjoy the Radio Silence ---- Chief announcer Mike Rayfield left for Micron. Oh my all we have is earnings, guidance, stock buybacks, and dividend increases.....

Message.Title: Fools say going to $10 before it blossoms in 5 #$%$ years!
Message.Msg: While this is certainly not the stock to be in for the short term, it is still a highly compelling long term play. With NVIDIA trading at $12.34, as of close 2/6/2013, a share and likely to go lower if the Google rumors prove to be true, this may be close to the ideal buying time. Remember buying low, selling high, is the name of the game. If you happen to already hold a significant stake in NVIDIA then I would be inclined to hold at this point, as the stock is not likely to break the $10 range. With an annual yield of 2.43% you can earn some interest while waiting for the stock to blossom, which it is likely to do within 5 years.
